Award.AwardTitle: ATD: Frame-Theoretic Information Fusion for Threat Detection
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses several emerging problems in the mathematical field of Hilbert space frames. This research has two thrusts. The first thrust involves using frame theory to provide sparse representations of data. Here, the project is concerned with the paramount problems of the field: to provide verifiable constructions of restricted isometry property (RIP) matrices of implementable size; to find algorithmic constructions of real and complex Grassmannian frames; to find frames which, in the sparsest possible manner, represent a given set of data. The second thrust involves using frame theory to fuse information gathered from disparate sensor modalities. Here, the work focuses on several fundamental open problems of multimodal data processing, such as how to mathematically determine what given collections of modalities yields optimal detection accuracies, and how data from different modes should be registered.

Recent advances in sensor hardware provide an unprecedented capability to detect the production, deployment and use of chemical and biological weapons. At the same time, the cost of misdetecting such threats is extremely high. Moreover, human intelligence analysts are increasingly overwhelmed by ever-larger data sets. The purpose of this project is to develop new mathematics which will help automate as much of this threat detection process as is possible, freeing human analysts to focus on the most high-level tasks. In particular, a good understanding of sparse representations allows one to break very complicated phenomena into a relatively small number of much-easier-to-understand pieces. Meanwhile, a good understanding of multimodal data allows one to combine data from many different sensors, in order to make a decision which is wiser than could be made from the data of any single sensor alone.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The support provided by this award led to the development of many new mathematical theories and algorithms.  These new theories and algorithms address several emerging engineering problems related to the detection of threats to national defense.  Most of the work concerns the remote sensing of chemical signatures.  This includes the hardware design of individual sensors, how a given set of sensors should be arranged into a sensor network, and how data from a sensor network should be combined in order to draw proper conclusions from it.  In particular, the project's results on "equiangular tight frames" and the "restricted isometry property" give better insight into how the next-generation of hyperspectral imagers should be designed so as to provide better quality sensing at a faster rate.  Next, the project's results on the "Paulsen problem" and related topics give algorithms for adjusting a given sensor network so as to make it more robust against noisy and/or unreliable sensor measurements.  Finally, the project's results on "fusion frames" highlights the potential usefulness of distributed processing in sensor networks. Though these new results were primarily developed to address defense-related applications involving threat detection, they also have a broad impact on numerous other fields.  This includes the mathematical field of compressed sensing, which is revolutionizing medical and seismic imaging.  These new results also pertain to important applications in the fields of wireless communication and quantum information theory.


Most of the award was used to provide a salary for several PhD students and postdoctoral researchers so that they could work full time on the aforementioned research.  The remaining funds were used to provide a partial salary for the senior personnel, as well as travel by these researchers, their PhD students and their postdoctoral advisees that was directly related to the project goals.  The primary deliverable of the project is the new mathematical theory and algorithms described above.  As detailed in the project's annual and final reports, this work was disseminated in numerous articles in top-tier, peer-reviewed scientific journals, as well as many conference proceedings and book chapters.  The work was also presented at many scientific conferences, program reviews and university seminars.  Much of the work is publicly available on arXiv.org as well as the website for the Frame Research Center.  A secondary, but equally important deliverable are the PhD students and postdoctoral researchers themselves.  By being supported by this program at the beginnings of their careers, there is a much better chance that these extremely bright and competent young researchers will spend their professional lifetimes working on mathematical problems crucial to the future development and defense of our nation.
